channel.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
channel.description:
For those of you who don't know people are absolutely freaking out because Chick-fil-A has been donating millions to an anti-samesex marriage campaign. I personally believe that if people have such a big problem with this, then they're pretty damn hypacritical because if you argue that they shouldn't support the campaign because "The gays should have rights to there own beliefs", yet you don't give Chick-fil-A a right to theres, then your just as bad as they are.
Also I don't really care about gay marriage because it's not like 2 men getting married is going to make life on earth stop.
Opinions?

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:23, topic:452801”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=555668.msg4068985#msg4068985 date=1344183445]

Where were the Boston/Chicago/San Francisco mayors when all he was doing was donating to anti-gay marriage programs?

Gee, I don’t know, maybe they were ignorant of the fact because it wasn’t common public knowledge?

So they attack a corporation for stating an opinion, not because they were donating to anti-gay marriage programs. That seems VERY tolerant of them.[/quote]

They’re “attacking” the corporation because they’re making donations to anti-gay programs, holy shit what about this are you not getting exactly?

Their opinion has nothing to do with it at this point, Chik-fil-a under the WinShape foundation are donating to anti-gay programs and that is why people are outraged, the fact that the CEO stating his opinion was the catalyst for the news exposure has nothing to do with it.

This is like talking to a brick wall honestly.[/quote]

“They” meaning the Mayors. The mayors wanted a ban on chick fil a because of Cathy’s statement. Not because they have been donating to anti-gay marriage programs.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“m1lkman, post:21, topic:452801”][quote author=Niall link=topic=555668.msg4068970#msg4068970 date=1344182270]

Where were the Boston/Chicago/San Francisco mayors when all he was doing was donating to anti-gay marriage programs?

Gee, I don’t know, maybe they were ignorant of the fact because it wasn’t common public knowledge?
[/quote]

So they attack a corporation for stating an opinion, not because they were donating to anti-gay marriage programs. That seems VERY tolerant of them.[/quote]

They’re “attacking” the corporation because they’re making donations to anti-gay programs, holy shit what about this are you not getting exactly?

Their opinion has nothing to do with it at this point, Chik-fil-a under the WinShape foundation are donating to anti-gay programs and that is why people are outraged, the fact that the CEO stating his opinion was the catalyst for the news exposure has nothing to do with it.

This is like talking to a brick wall honestly.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

“What would you say about the Salvation Army though? They match the definition of a charity but seek to discriminate against homosexuals.”
What is the primary goal of Salvation Army, charity or banning Gay Marriage? I would consider them a charity as I don’t see them as an anti-gay organisation.

In the same way I don’t consider the Catholic Church as an anti-condom organization. Their focus isn’t on banning condoms, it just one of their many views.

While I think no organization that discriminate against people should get tax reduction or government money, and no organization should be able to lobby. Salvation Army isn’t the big problem.

Milkman:
It isn’t intolerance to fight against intolerance. You must also remember that politicians are playing a game, make people vote for you.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=m1lkman link=topic=555668.msg4068965#msg4068965 date=1344181822]Where were the Boston/Chicago/San Francisco mayors when all he was doing was donating to anti-gay marriage programs?

Gee, I don’t know, maybe they were ignorant of the fact because it wasn’t common public knowledge?[/quote]

So they attack a corporation for stating an opinion, not because they were donating to anti-gay marriage programs. That seems VERY tolerant of them.

Niall:

[quote author=m1lkman link=topic=555668.msg4068965#msg4068965 date=1344181822]Then all of a sudden him donating to anti-gay marriage funds is why they should be banned, not him stating his opinion, even though they have been donating all along.

Did you know that Chik-fil-a were donating to anti-gay programs before this hit the news? Because chances are you wouldn’t have until you looked into it, and chances are you wouldn’t have looked into it unless you had some obligation to do so.[/quote]

No, I didn’t know that they were donating to anti-gay marriage programs but if I was asked if they were against gay marriage, I would use my common sense and say yes.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

m1lkman:

Where were the Boston/Chicago/San Francisco mayors when all he was doing was donating to anti-gay marriage programs?

Gee, I don’t know, maybe they were ignorant of the fact because it wasn’t common public knowledge?

A scandal isn’t a scandal until it’s been exposed and that can’t happen until the media blow it out of proportion, usually to the effect of blocking all other news out. Speaking of which, did anyone notice that Obama signed the patriot act extentio–HEY GUYS CHIK-FIL-A CONTROVERSY

m1lkman:

Then all of a sudden him donating to anti-gay marriage funds is why they should be banned, not him stating his opinion, even though they have been donating all along.

Did you know that Chik-fil-a were donating to anti-gay programs before this hit the news? Because chances are you wouldn’t have until you looked into it, and chances are you wouldn’t have looked into it unless you had some obligation to do so.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=m1lkman link=topic=555668.msg4068827#msg4068827 date=1344169076]Niall, they have ALWAYS been donating to anti-gay programs. The fire only started when he was ASKED about gay marriage and everyone was shocked at the answer.

I never said they have only recently started donating. The US media arguably blew the whole thing out of proportion, yes, but it doesn’t change what people are outraged about.[/quote]

Where were the Boston/Chicago/San Francisco mayors when all he was doing was donating to anti-gay marriage programs? They didn’t say anything until he stated his opinion. Then all of a sudden him donating to anti-gay marriage funds is why they should be banned, not him stating his opinion, even though they have been donating all along. The people who blew this whole thing out of proportion were the politicians, not the media.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Bowser jr:

Niall: Why are you calling them anti-gay charities?

What I meant to say was, anti-gay charities and organizations. They may not fit the strict definition of a charity, but Chik-fil-a has donated to several tax-exempt non-profit organizations which may fit the legal definition of a charity. The fault is mine, I usually consider any non-profit organization to be a charity, part of my nomenclature I guess.

What would you say about the Salvation Army though? They match the definition of a charity but seek to discriminate against homosexuals.

m1lkman:

Niall, they have ALWAYS been donating to anti-gay programs. The fire only started when he was ASKED about gay marriage and everyone was shocked at the answer.

I never said they have only recently started donating. The US media arguably blew the whole thing out of proportion, yes, but it doesn’t change what people are outraged about.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

The “NO GAY MARRIAGE” rule.

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Bowser jr:

m1lkman: Sorry I’m somewhat tired. My point is that people cherry pick religious laws. They don’t keep the Sunday holy, and they don’t keep their marriages as promised. When a religious rule doesn’t affect them, they would support it.

What religious rule is hurting gay people? Being closed on Sundays?

I still don’t understand what you are driving at.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:13, topic:452801”]m1lkman: The thing is that it is one of the religious stuff that Americans does not care about. Keeping religious rules are great of it is just gays that suffers, but people won’t give up their Sunday shopping.
One rule is good, the other one is outrageous.[/quote]

What are you talking about?

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:11, topic:452801”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=555668.msg4068827#msg4068827 date=1344169076]
“Let’s ask a business owner whose business is closed on sunday about gay marriage and be shocked at the answer”
[/quote]
Funny thing, stores are not allowed to be open on Sundays here (With some small exceptions.) I like how nobody is lobbying for that in US.[/quote]

There used to be a law in the US where stores weren’t allowed to be open on Sundays.

en.wikipedia.org

Blue law

Blue laws, also known as Sunday laws, are laws designed to restrict or ban some or all Sunday activities for religious reasons, particularly to promote the observance of a day of worship or rest. Blue laws may also restrict shopping or ban sale of certain items on specific days, most often on Sundays in the western world. Blue laws are enforced in parts of the United States and Canada as well as some European countries, particularly in Austria, Germany, Switzerland, and Norway, keeping most store...

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

m1lkman:

“Let’s ask a business owner whose business is closed on sunday about gay marriage and be shocked at the answer”

Funny thing, stores are not allowed to be open on Sundays here (With some small exceptions.) I like how nobody is lobbying for that in US.

The thing is that people take action when they are aware of the problem. People are now aware that Chick-fil-A is bigots and against civil rights, so they do something about it.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=Cowarooroo link=topic=555668.msg4067924#msg4067924 date=1344071743]then they’re pretty damn hypacritical because if you argue that they shouldn’t support the campaign because “The gays should have rights to there own beliefs”, yet you don’t give Chick-fil-A a right to theres, then your just as bad as they are.

for the millionth pissing time, a simple belief or opinion stops being a belief or opinion once you act upon it

it’s fine for chik-fil-a to say gays shouldn’t be marriage because that’s merely an opinion which is protected under the first amendment, however by donating millions to anti-gay charities seeking to outlaw same-sex marriage, chik-fil-a are acting upon their opinion and joining the movement to prevent giving civil rights to same sex couples and that’s why people are outraged at chik-fil-a

I just had to bold a few parts because it isn’t a matter of opinion that same-sex marriages should be legal, it’s a matter of civil fucking rights

EDIT: this gets posted a lot but I feel it’s relevant - http://i.imgur.com/GtdEX.jpg[/quote]

Niall, they have ALWAYS been donating to anti-gay programs. The fire only started when he was ASKED about gay marriage and everyone was shocked at the answer.

“Let’s ask a business owner whose business is closed on sunday about gay marriage and be shocked at the answer”

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @gothic_queen casey.
item.description:
@gothic_queen wrote:

Have no problem with a company voicing its opinion and am a supporter of them upholding it.

Plus, the food is great.

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Niall: Why are you calling them anti-gay charities?

I was looking up the definition and they are clearly not charities. The definition according to Oxford Dictionary is:

  1. An organization set up to provide help and raise money for those in need.
  2. The voluntary giving of help, typically in the form of money, to those
  3. Kindness and tolerance in judging others.

Where is the charity in lobbying for intolerance?

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:5, topic:452801”][quote author=Niall link=topic=555668.msg4068077#msg4068077 date=1344092289]

then they’re pretty damn hypacritical because if you argue that they shouldn’t support the campaign because “The gays should have rights to there own beliefs”, yet you don’t give Chick-fil-A a right to theres, then your just as bad as they are.

for the millionth pissing time, a simple belief or opinion stops being a belief or opinion once you act upon it

it’s fine for chik-fil-a to say gays shouldn’t be marriage because that’s merely an opinion which is protected under the first amendment, however by donating millions to anti-gay charities seeking to outlaw same-sex marriage, chik-fil-a are acting upon their opinion and joining the movement to prevent giving civil rights to same sex couples and that’s why people are outraged at chik-fil-a

I just had to bold a few parts because it isn’t a matter of opinion that same-sex marriages should be legal, it’s a matter of civil fucking rights

EDIT: this gets posted a lot but I feel it’s relevant - http://i.imgur.com/GtdEX.jpg
[/quote]
You know, I think those people in the older imagine are the same in the newer one… :s[/quote]

Wouldn’t surprise me if a few of them were, haha.

Read full topic

item.title: The Chick-fil-A Dispute
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Krackkid, post:3, topic:452801”]Well with my mom a lesbian and my grandma a strong christian…I don’t side with any of it I just find it all funny.

Also [quote author=sinisoul link=topic=555668.msg4067952#msg4067952 date=1344074343]
Don’t care, love their food.
[/quote][/quote]that must be hell at family reunions :o

[hr]

I don’t really care either way about the dispute. People are going to try to get equal rights either way, I’m surprised the police were not called in for crowding the streets.

Read full topic

I personally believe that if people have such a big problem with this, then they’re pretty damn hypacritical because if you argue that they shouldn’t support the campaign because “The gays should have rights to there own beliefs”, yet you don’t give Chick-fil-A a right to theres, then your just as bad as they are.
